So I’m going to talk about the varieties
of verbal hallucinations and here’s the

19.text:
structure of my talk. First I’m going to
ask what roughly is a verbal hallucination

27.text:
and then I’m going to justify the terminological
choice of verbal hallucination because the

35.text:
standard terminology is auditory verbal hallucination
and then I’m going to go through some varieties

42.text:
of verbal hallucinations but there aren’t
only varieties, there are also varieties of

48.text:
varieties, so there are different dimensions
across which they can vary. And then I’m

55.text:
going to ask well what do we do in the face
of all this variety, this overwhelming variety?

61.text:
And I’m going to end with some tentative
suggestions for what might be called ‘sub-types’.

68.text:
OK, so what roughly is a verbal hallucination?
Well roughly it involves hearing a voice in

76.text:
the absence of a speaker. So at the moment
the room is relatively silent apart from me

85.text:
speaking and if I were to stop speaking and
then I told you that I was hearing a voice,

91.text:
even though the room was silent, you might
think I was having a verbal hallucination.

98.text:
And like I said, in the scientific and clinical
literature, this tends to be called auditory

105.text:
verbal hallucination, or AVH for short. However,
there are – I’m not too happy with that

115.text:
particular way of referring to them because
there are so-called soundless voices. So verbal

123.text:
hallucinations as Chris Frith says are ‘often
an experience of receiving a communication

128.text:
without any sensory component’, and in fact
the phenomenon of soundless voices has been

134.text:
reported as far back as Janet in – or Janet
I think – in 1889 and Bleuler in 1911 and

143.text:
it’s been quite widely discussed since.
So it’s perhaps surprising that some theorists

149.text:
kind of seem to overlook this. So for example
you’ve got Garrett and Silva saying ‘the

153.text:
subjective quality of sensation is a near
universal feature of auditory hallucinations’.

161.text:
Of course it could be that they’re not exactly
overlooking the fact that soundless voices

165.text:
exist, they might just be delineating the
phenomenon that interests them in terms of

172.text:
an auditory experience. But for reasons that
I don’t have time to go into, I think it’s

181.text:
more relevant to lump the soundless but verbal
hallucinations together with the auditory

190.text:
verbal hallucinations and to put auditory
hallucinations that aren’t verbal to one

200.text:
OK, so a recent questionnaire that – it
was a study that was conducted by researchers

209.text:
at Durham on the project that I’m currently
on so it was a questionnaire filled in by

215.text:
153 voice hearers from clinical and non-clinical
populations and they found a large number

221.text:
of cases where voices were sometimes, or always,
reported as non-auditory. OK, so here’s

228.text:
an example. These are the responses to the
questionnaire filled in by voice hearers.

236.text:
‘it’s hard to describe how I could hear
a voice that wasn't auditory, but the words

240.text:
used and the emotions they contained – hatred
and disgust – were completely clear, distinct

246.text:
and unmistakeable. Maybe even more so than
if I’d heard them aurally’, ‘there are

251.text:
things I hear that aren’t as much like truly
hearing a voice or voices. Instead these are

256.text:
more like telepathy or hearing without hearing
exactly, but knowing that content has been

261.text:
exchanged and feeling that happen’. Also,
apart from soundless voices among people who

270.text:
can hear you also get reports of verbal hallucinations
in congenitally deaf people. So Jo Atkinson,

278.text:
a congenitally deaf researcher in London,
writes this, ‘around half of all deaf people

287.text:
diagnosed with schizophrenia report experiencing
voices during which they sense someone communicating

293.text:
with them in the absence of any external stimulus.
Individuals claim they were lip reading a

298.text:
vague visual percept but could not clearly
see a face, or felt that they were being finger

304.text:
spelt to by a persecutor but were unable to
see the hands distinctly. What’s interesting

309.text:
about this paper is that it actually corrects
– this paper in 2006 corrected the orthodox

315.text:
view which was that a congenitally deaf person
with schizophrenia would have an auditory

321.text:
experience and in fact the reason why people
were misled to think that was because the

328.text:
way in which the congenitally deaf voice hearers
were interviewed was phrased in audio-centric

337.text:
ways. So loudness for example would actually
be more to do with the intrusive nature of

343.text:
the experience rather than something actually
auditory.

347.text:
OK, so so far I’ve briefly presented what
a verbal hallucination is and I’ve justified

355.text:
to some extent my terminological choice. I’m
still not happy with verbal hallucination.

361.text:
I’m not too happy with verbal and I’m
not too happy with hallucination but it’s

364.text: an improvement on auditory verbal hallucination.

367.text:
OK, so onto varieties of variety. So there
are varieties in the context of the currents,

376.text:
so it’s fairly common to think that if somebody
hears a voice, they’ve got schizophrenia

385.text:
or perhaps the more sort of folky conception
is if you hear a voice you’re crazy. So

394.text:
first off it’s not just in schizophrenia
that you get verbal hallucinations. So you

398.text:
get it in schizo-effective disorder, bipolar
disorder, depression, anxiety disorders, PTSD,

403.text:
OCD, borderline personality disorder and of
course you can also question whether schizophrenia

411.text:
or any of these categories are even valid
categories, but the point is that people who

416.text:
have these diagnoses report verbal hallucinations.
But even individuals without any clinical

425.text:
diagnosis at all and who are not in need of
care report hearing voices.

435.text:
So there are also varieties in the apparent
nature of the phenomenon itself. So bracketing

444.text:
what diagnosis you have, bracketing the potential
underlying mechanisms, what is it like to

450.text:
have these experiences and the answer is it
varies enormously from person to person and

455.text:
sometimes within a person from experience
to experience. So we’ve seen that they vary

464.text:
to the extent that they are described or experienced
as auditory at all but also they vary across

472.text:
a dimension of loudness, so they can be loud
or they can be quiet. They can be internal

477.text:
or external so they can be located inside
the head or outside, or even sometimes in

483.text:
a part of their body. So they’ll say ‘I’m
hearing this coming from my leg’, They vary

489.text:
in complexity, so the complexity of what is
actually said by the voice. So sometimes they’ll

495.text:
be short so like a one-word expletive, sometimes
they’ll be long, they’ll be a complex

500.text:
commentary. Sometimes people will be able
to actually interact with their voices. They

507.text:
vary in personification. So a voice is not
just an auditory experience, it’s attached

514.text:
to an agent, to an individual often with its
own perspective. Often voice hearers report

521.text:
that when they don’t hear the voice, when
they’re not having the auditory experience,

525.text:
or the experience of being communicated with,
‘the voice’ as in the person, is still

529.text:
there, still watching them, still commenting
or still ready to comment on what they do.

537.text:
So there are degrees of personification. So
sometimes it’s very sparse, sometimes it’s

542.text:
like ‘well, I know it’s a man who’s
very angry’ and sometimes the voice hearers

549.text:
will give them names. Sometimes they’ll
actually correspond to pre-existing individuals,

556.text:
whether fictional or real. So they could be
celebrities, they could be someone from the

563.text:
person’s past. And also they vary in the
types of speech acts that are heard. So sometimes

570.text:
they’re insults, sometimes they’re commands,
commentaries, warnings. Sometimes they’re

575.text:
reassurance, so in the context of bereavement
you often get people report verbal hallucinations

582.text:
that are often very reassuring ‘it’s OK,
I’m still here’, that sort of thing. And

587.text:
then there are sort of miscellaneous experiences
like crowd noises, shouts, screams, moans

593.text:
and things that also don’t seem to come
from a human source, so sort of honks, bells,

600.text:
whistles. I think those should be put slightly
to one side. You also get varieties of verbal

608.text:
hallucination within one individual, as I
said. So these are from the questionnaire

614.text:
study that we ran and that was reported in
a recent paper in Lancet Psychiatry but not

624.text:
all of the questionnaires, because there were
153 of them, were actually reported in that

629.text:
paper so some of these aren’t actually from
the paper but I’ve numbered them, but here

634.text:
are cases of one person reporting two different
kinds of voice. ‘So the voice inside my

639.text:
head sounds nothing like a real person talking
to me, but rather like another person’s

644.text:
thoughts in my head. The other voices are
to me indistinguishable from actual people

648.text:
talking in the same room as me. I feel like
I’ve other people’s thoughts in my head

655.text:
and also hear other people having conversations
outside my head’. OK, so I won’t read

663.text: them all out but you get the idea.

668.text:
So it’s been kind of overwhelming since
coming on this project and interacting with

676.text:
voice hearers and finding, really getting
immersed in all of this qualitative data that

684.text:
the variety of voice hearing is about as varied
as you could imagine it to be. If you can

690.text:
think up a variation, it probably exists.
So what to do in the face of all this variety?

700.text:
And the reason why you might be motivated
to do something in the face of all this variety

705.text:
is that treatment options and coping strategies
will be very different for different people

711.text:
with different histories and experiencing
different things. So although this may be

715.text:
very difficult to do, there should be at least
an attempt to isolate sub-types of verbal

720.text:
hallucination. And the pay-off would be a
better diagnosis and more effective treatment.

726.text:
So here are two nice examples of this sort
of pay-off. So instead of going ‘right,

735.text:
you’re a voice hearer and you’re very
distressed by your voices so I’m going to

741.text:
give you a diagnosis of schizophrenia and
I’m going to put you on anti-psychotics’.

746.text:
Instead of doing that, I mean I know that’s
a very caricatural [sic] way of talking but

752.text:
just illustratively, here are two nice examples
where things were slightly different. So in

762.text:
this paper by Stefane et al. they report two
patients who heard voices so they reported

770.text:
them as voice hearing experiences but the
content was very similar to intrusions in

777.text:
OCD, ‘do that and something bad’s going
to happen’ and they didn’t respond to

784.text:
anti-psychotics but they did respond to fluvoxamine,
the anti-OCD medication. And in Kuiper’s

794.text:
et al 2006 they report a bunch of patients
who didn’t respond well to anti-psychotics

799.text:
but the verbal hallucinations that they experienced
were often preceded by heightened anxiety

807.text:
and then they report that treating the anxiety
significantly lowers both the frequency and

818.text:
So now onto the suggestions for sub-types.
There’s a long history of sub-types, so

825.text:
Claude and Ey in 1932 talked about an insight
present sub-group and a repetitive content

833.text:
sub-group, and Jaspers famously has got the
distinction between pseudo-hallucinations

837.text:
and hallucinations proper. None of these have
proved robustly useful for differentiating

844.text:
effective treatment options and more recent
attempts to sub-type have used really quite

853.text:
sophisticated cluster analysis. So you’ve
got from that same paper that I mentioned

859.text:
earlier, the Stefane et al paper, they say
that there's one kind of – they referred

865.text:
to them as AVHs – one kind of AVH characterised
by low complexity perceived in outer space

870.text:
– sorry, ‘outer space’ as in not out
there – and repetitive content. One of AVH

880.text:
characterised by high complexity ‘inner
space’ so in your head and multiple voices.

886.text:
McCarthy Jones et al had other clusters as
well, so distinguishing non-verbal auditory

893.text:
hallucinations, constant and commanding auditory
hallucinations, own thoughts auditory verbal

900.text:
hallucinations and replays. But these are
phenomenological rather than etiological sub-types.

907.text:
So they’re saying ‘this is what it’s
like to undergo the experience’ and in principle

912.text:
you could have constant and commanding AVHs
that are etiological very different. At least

917.text:
in principle you could have that. You’d
be justified in thinking that the phenomenology,

922.text:
all other things being equal, would be a good
indicator of etiology but in principle you

931.text:
have the same phenomenology with different
etiologies – or very similar phenomenologies.

936.text:
So these things don’t tell us about underlying
mechanisms and surely that’s what we should

942.text: look for to inform our interventions.

946.text:
So here is Allen, Aleman and McGuire talking
about different etiologies of verbal hallucinations.

956.text:
They say although all these accounts have
important differences, they all propose that

961.text:
internally generated thoughts and images are
mistaken for externally generated events and

968.text:
I think this is true of only the first two
of my three suggested sub-types. OK, so in

974.text:
a paper published last year I build pretty
heavily on work done by Guy Dodgson who works

983.text:
on our project. So the three sub-types are
inner speech hallucinations, memory based

988.text:
hallucinations and hyper-vigilance hallucinations
and all of these views when first introduced

994.text:
are kind of presented as competing accounts
of the same phenomenon when in fact perhaps

1000.text:
they should be seen as potentially equally
good accounts of different sub-types. So inner

1008.text:
speech based hallucinations, the idea is that
self-generated inner speech, so that voice

1016.text:
in your head when you talk to yourself, for
some reason and there are different theories

1022.text:
that suggest different explanations, attributed
to an external source. These usually are aggravated

1028.text:
by silence and loneliness and listening to
music and focusing on talking to somebody

1032.text:
else often helps. These are all sometimes
experienced as non-auditory and occur in the

1038.text:
context of depression, low self-esteem, anxiety.
The content of what is said by the voice might

1045.text:
be complex and discursive. So Philip had become
acutely unwell leading to a hospital admission.

1051.text:
He described intrusive critical voices; they
typically provided a running commentary on

1056.text:
his activities and happened more often when
he was alone and focused on his own thought.

1061.text:
Philip was encouraged to try to block out
the inner speech with humming and listening

1064.text:
to music. He was also encouraged to transform
the voice into something comic. This reduced

1069.text:
his distress and the voices started to reduce
in frequency. So then there are memory based

1074.text:
hallucinations which basically do the same
thing. They say right, there’s something

1077.text:
that you’re producing but you’re failing
to recognise it as self-produced. And these

1084.text:
tend to fit with AVHs that tend to be the
upshot of a traumatic experience. So you’ll

1091.text:
often get, the voices will often be recognisably
that of a past abuser and you might ask as

1100.text:
well, you know, is there a connection here
with PTSD. My traumatic memory’s been coded

1105.text:
in such a way with these vivid flashbacks
that contextual views that normally enable

1110.text:
you to recognise memories as memories, are
not available. OK, so here’s a case vignette

1117.text:
that I haven’t got time to read. So there’s
abuse and the realisation that his voices

1128.text: are connected to trauma helps a lot.

1135.text:
OK, so finally hyper-vigilance hallucinations.
So Dodgson and Gordon were the first to, I

1142.text:
think, were the first to introduce hyper-vigilance
hallucinations and later on Garwood et al

1152.text:
2013, they noted that AVHs occur when attention
is directed inwards and in quiet context,

1165.text:
or, when attention is directed outwards and
in loud context. So they thought that that

1170.text:
provided good grounds for at least those two
sub-types. And here’s a case vignette. Michael

1179.text:
was experiencing a series of stresses, including
break-up with a girlfriend and exclusion from

1184.text:
seeing their child, heavy street drug use
including amphetamines and a pending court

1188.text:
case for arson. He began to experience auditory
hallucinations, hearing people calling him

1192.text:
a nonce. Michael began to believe that people
could read his thoughts and that people thought

1198.text:
he was a paedophile. So here it’s interesting
that there you’ve got very much like a one-word

1205.text:
verbal hallucination and these occur in states
of hyper-vigilance, they involve ambiguous

1213.text:
external stimuli that are being boosted and
shaped by fears and expectations. So unlike

1219.text:
that very general claim that Alan et al make,
it doesn’t seem to have involved a self-produced

1227.text:
raw material, it’s actually something external
that gets boosted up and these will tend to

1232.text:
be experienced as auditory externally located
and simple in context. So one-word insults

1238.text: like we saw in the case.

1241.text: So yeah, lots of ticks there. Thanks for listening.
